Context:
The Centre for Business at George Brown College offers a Business Administration diploma program with ACBSP accreditation. There are fourteen programs in the Centre for Business that have earned international recognition from ACBSP, including Advanced Diploma and Diploma programs in Accounting and Finance, Human Resources, Management, Marketing, and the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program. This program is also offered with work experience (B155).

George Brown College aims to provide field education opportunities with real-world challenges and clients in addition to on-the-job work experience. Graduates are prepared for various administrative and management positions in a broad range of employment settings. The B145 program requires completion of 36 courses: 27 mandatory courses, 6 Business electives, and 3 General Education electives. Students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) and MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) before progressing to other courses, which do not count toward the 36 courses required for graduation. Students must complete three General Education courses from at least two different areas in semesters 4, 5, and 6.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Business Administration Program B145 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
You must complete three General Education courses from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI). Students are required to make up any failed or dropped courses before graduation. Continuing Education offers some courses that can be taken in the evening, but students must check with the business office staff to ensure their equivalence to full-time program courses. Not all courses may be offered every semester.

Courses for Semester 1:
- BUS 1038: Business Concepts I (NONE)
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts (NONE)
- COMP 1010: Business Computer Applications I (NONE)
- HRM 1008: Fundamentals of HR Management (NONE)
- MARK 1020: Principles of Marketing I (NONE)
- MATH 1008: Math for Business & Management I (NONE)

Courses for Semester 2:
- ECON 1031: Microeconomics (NONE)
- BUS 1040: Project Management (NONE)
- COMM 1034: Professional Communications I (COMM 2000 as prerequisite)
- COMP 1115: Business Computer Applications II (COMP 1010 as prerequisite)
- MATH 1095: Math for Business & Management II
- MATH 1008: Math for Business & Management I
- PSY 1129: Organizational Behaviour (NONE)

Courses for Semester 3:
- ACCT 1036: Principles of Accounting (NONE)
- CMMK 1087: Human Skills (NONE)
- ECON 1032: Macroeconomics (NONE)
- MARK 1002: Professional Selling (MARK 1020 as prerequisite)
- MGMT 4009: Operations Management
- MATH 1008: Business Statistics
- STAT 1012: Business Statistics
- MATH 1095: Math for Business & Management II

Courses for Semester 4:
- ACCT 2031: Managerial Accounting (ACCT 1036 as prerequisite)
- BUS 1041: Small Business Management
- BUS 1038: Business Concepts I or Business Law (NONE)
- MGMT 2049: Supply Chain.

Context:
The text provides information about the courses offered in Semesters 5 and 6 for a program at the college. Here are some key factual details extracted from the text:

- Courses offered in Semester 5 include: Business Law (BUS 1044), Supply Chain Management II (MGMT 2049), Career Planning & Development (STS 1037), Quality Improvement through Lean/Six Sigma (MGMT 4009 & ACCT 2031), Strategic Analysis (MGMT 3006), and Applied Business Planning (BUS 3015). Some courses have prerequisites, such as MGMT 1020 for Management Decision-Making.
- Courses offered in Semester 6 include: Strategic Analysis (MGMT 3006), International Sales and Marketing (MGMT 2041), Procurement (MGMT 2049 & BUS 1044), Negotiation Skills (MARK 2053), Retail Management (MGMT 2037), and Retail Marketing (MGMT 1034). Some courses have multiple prerequisites, such as MGMT 1020 & COMM 1034 for Strategic Analysis.
- Students are required to select one General Education Elective in each semester.
- The business electives offered include Field Education Course (BUS 1067), Business Research & Report Writing (CMMK 1114), Principles of E-Business (COMP 1113), Coaching for Effective Performance Management (HRM 2027), and several marketing, management, and mathematics courses. Some electives have specific prerequisites or application requirements, such as HRM 2027 and by interview only for Field Based Advanced Coaching.
- The program learning outcomes include the ability to evaluate the impact of global issues on an organization's business opportunities by using an environmental scan, and applying principles of corporate sustainability, corporate social responsibility, and ethics to support an organization.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Business Administration Program B145 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about various skills and knowledge areas required for business students at George Brown College, as well as tuition fees and financial assistance details. Here is the extracted information:

1. Skills and Knowledge Areas:
   - Conduct environmental scans and apply principles of corporate sustainability, corporate social responsibility, and ethics to support an organization’s business initiatives.
   - Assess and use current concepts/systems and technologies to support an organization's business initiatives.
   - Conduct research to support business decision-making.
   - Plan, implement, and evaluate projects using project management principles.
   - Perform work in compliance with relevant statutes, regulations, and business practices.
   - Apply human resource practices to support management objectives and the organization’s goals.
   - Use accounting and financial principles to support the management and operations of an organization.
   - Assess marketing and sales concepts and strategies and apply them to the needs of an organization.
   - Outline principles of supply chain management and operations management and assess their impact on the operations of an organization.
   - Participate in the development of a business plan.
   - Develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development to enhance work performance in the business field.
   - Outline strategies used to manage risks in an organization's business activities.

2. Tuition Fees:
   - Domestic Tuition: $3,798.00 (first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023)
   - International Tuition: $17,925.00 (first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2024)
   - Note: These fees do not include books and are subject to change without notice.

3. Financial Assistance:
   - This program is approved for OSAP funding if the applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria.

4. Admission Requirements:
   - Applicants are selected based on academic achievement, including required courses and other selection criteria.

5. Miscellaneous:
   - The information in the text is subject to change without notice.
   - Students are responsible for verifying George Brown College fee requirements.
   - International students should refer to the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.

Context:
To apply for a program at George Brown College, applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, with a grade 12 English (C or U) and either a grade 11 Math (C, M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students who are 19 years of age or older and do not have an OSSD can take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math or upgrade to achieve the required credits. Some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions, and proficiency in English communications is necessary.

International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System and visit the International Admissions page for country-specific requirements. Information sessions are held regularly, and applicants can contact the Admissions Office for domestic queries or the international recruitment representatives for international queries. The Financial Aid Office can be contacted for inquiries about OSAP, bursaries, scholarships, and other financial matters.

There is no explicit mention of a specific program offered by the college in the provided text.
